This is a small Arcade Cabinet originally made for a colleague. It's laser cut and has nearly no visible screws or other things distracting the eye.

It's powered by Raspberry Pi 2 or 3 together with the original Raspberry Pi 7" Touchscreen which I wanted to use for something for a long time.

Detailed instructions

I'd be super happy if you would vote for me in the "Full Spectrum Laser" contest if you like this project! Thank you!

description.text:
This is a simple hook that's designed to keep my wife happy. Happy wife, happy life!

We have a shower wall made out of glass in our bathroom that my wife put a simple door hanger on. Because of the risks with mounting something that's waaay bigger than supposed I came up with a simple design that fits like a glove.

The hook is designed with a longer than normal back to fasten securely and a frame that's thin but durable. It has an inner distance of 6mm. The front is deep enough to take both clothes as well as towels and the lip that secures everything is big enough to keep the items from falling down. I also had speed in mind and this one prints fast.

remixed_from.author: CrazyMonkeyBen
remixed_from.title: Case for Pi 2/B+ w/ Adafruit PiTFT

description.text:
Introduction

I have a Wanhao Duplicator i3, a raspberry pi 2 running octoprint (the octopi image), an LED light over the printer, and a 4 relay board from sainsmart.

There are places with instructions, tips, etc. But I wanted to share how I did it with this specific printer, and I wanted to illustrate exactly how I managed to control the printer power, and the light, with some rudamentary automation.

CAUTION

Duh, this is AC power. The printer can create a lot of juice, but it's nothing compared to the power coming from the walls. This can definitely kill you, so be cautious. If you don't know what you're doing, then stop.

GPIO Scripts

octopi comes with the gpio stuff installed, so just running "gpio" on the command line gives me several options. I made 4 scripts to control the relays. They were all in "/usr/local/bin/". I had to make them as root, and I had to add permissions "sudo chmod a+rx .sh" so that the pi user could execute them.

printer_on.sh:

#!/bin/bash
gpio export 23 out
gpio -g write 23 0

printer_off.sh:

#!/bin/bash
gpio export 23 out
gpio -g write 23 1

light_on.sh:

#!/bin/bash
gpio export 18 out
gpio -g write 18 0

light_off.sh:

#!/bin/bash
gpio export 18 out
gpio -g write 18 1

You can see, I wired GPIO 18 to the control of the light relay, and 23 to the control of the printer power relay.

You can also see that since I used the normally open connection, the signal is reversed (0 is on and 1 is off).

OctoPrint Config

So that's cool. I can type 'light_on.sh' and see the light turn on. But I don't want to ssh into the machine to do that, I want to use the octopi web interface.

The configuration for octopi is /home/pi/.octoprint/config.yaml

So, to let me run these commands from the "system" menu, I added this to my config:

system:
  actions:
  - action: pon
    command: printer_on.sh
    name: PrinterOn
  - action: poff
    command: printer_off.sh
    confirm: Are you sure you want to turn off the printer?
    name: PrinterOff
  - action: lon
    command: light_on.sh
    name: LightOn
  - action: loff
    command: light_off.sh
    name: LightOff

That gave me control of the lights, and printer from the system menu.

OctoPrint Config Part Two

That wasn't enough. I really wanted the lights to only be on when I'm printing, and I want the printer to be on when I restart the raspberry pi. So I also added this to the config. (See more details on the events part of the config here (http://docs.octoprint.org/en/master/events/index.html)

events:
  enabled: true
  subscriptions:
  - command:
    - printer_on.sh
    - light_off.sh
    event: Startup
    type: system
  - command: light_on.sh
    event: PrintStarted
    type: system
  - command: light_off.sh
    event: PrintFailed
    type: system
  - command: light_off.sh
    event: PrintCancelled
    type: system
  - command: light_off.sh
    event: PrintDone
    type: system

What this does (if you can't tell by reading it) is that when octopi starts (Startup) it will turn on the printer, and off the lights. When a print starts (PrintStarted) it will turn on the lights. When a print fails, is cancelled, or finished correctly, it will turn off the light. I probably could have used the CaptureStart and CaptureDone events, because that's really more of what I need, but this is working.

I went ahead and tested all of that using just the relay board before I connected up the printer or light. Just trying to make fewer really big mistakes here.

Wiring the Relay Board

I have a PiTFT screen, which is supposed to run OctoPiPanel. I haven't gotten that to work yet, but it does leave me with a challenge to wire up the relay. I don't have access to the general GPIO pins, because there is a screen on there. The screen covers the regular pins, but also provides them on another connector on the right side of the screen. For the relay board, I just soldered directly to the back of that connector. I only needed 4 wires, and they are as follows:

Pi Pin Relay Pin
5V Vcc
Gnd Gnd
23 IN1
18 IN2

Connecting Printer Power

The power supply from Wanhao is noisy, and annoying. I would have preferred to control low voltage DC signals, but I want that power supply off too. So I chose to control the 120VAC that powers the power supply. The power going to the power supply comes from the connector, goes through the switch on the back, and then goes to the power supply and is attached with a screw. I took a picture of which wire I disconnected from the power supply, but be careful, yours might be different.

I ran that cable out to the relay board, and I ran another cable back into the control box to that spot on the power supply. I just ran the cables next to the fan, but I should print a new back, with a hole in it for these cables.

I wired the relay so that if the relay board loses power for some reason, then the printer will be shut off (Normally Open). Now that I think about it, I don't really like it that way, maybe I'll reverse it later.

Connecting LED Light

I have an LED light that illuminates the desk that the printer is on. I opened it up, and there's clearly a 120VAC cable coming in, and a power supply to convert the power to DC, likely a lot lower voltage, like 12, or 24V. I decided to put the relay on this lower DC line, instead. So I cut that cable, soldered in a 2 conductor wire, and ran both to the NO part of the second relay.

Part Links

This is the relay board I used:
http://www.sainsmart.com/4-channel-5v-relay-module-for-pic-arm-avr-dsp-arduino-msp430-ttl-logic.html
This is the cover I used:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:957292

Update to work with PushBullet plugin

I use the Push Bullet plugin, and it sends me a photo at the end of every print. Unfortunately, it was taking the snapshot right after the lights went off :). So I modified the lights_off script like this, so that it will wait 5 seconds before turning off the lights, and wouldn't block the octopi running the job:

light_off.sh

#!/bin/bash
gpio export 18 out
(sleep 5 && gpio -g write 18 1)&

I first changed this:

gpio -g write 18 1

into this:

sleep 5
gpio -g write 18 1

And that worked fine, but someone told me that would be making octoprint stall for 5 seconds while it was doing that sleep (I don't believe them, but it was a very reputable source).

So I changed that to this:

(sleep 5 && gpio -g write 18 1)&

"sleep 5" waits five seconds. "&&" means that the first command has to complete with success, and then the second command will be called, so "sleep 5 && command" will wait five seconds, and call "command".

Putting that thing in parenthesis, and adding a "&" at the end means the whole thing will get run in the background, so that octoprint can keep on doing whatever it was doing before calling that script, wihtout waiting for the sleep or the command to finish.

comments.author: bestwon96

comments.text: Hello, I have this same SainSmart 4-channel 5v relay that you have. Here's my issue, I would REALLY appreciate your input (or anyone's in the know, I suppose). So there are many sources claiming that with this exact relay board, to control it using the Rpi, you need to solder 1kohm resistors over the existing ones in order for the 3.3v of the Rpi to control the 5v relays. However, there are clearly others who don't seem to have done this and are controlling it just fine. Did you need to do this? Do I need to do this? I'm trying to do exactly what you've done, I just want to be able to remotely power on and off my printer, and a light. Though my Octopi setup is powered through my 3D printer's PSU via a 12v to 5v step down converter, so I will need the main power supply to remain on at all times.
comments.author: gamertaboo

comments.text: In case you're wondering where I'm seeing this information, here it is. The second link I just found while searching for a picture of the mod, because the image link is broken on the Github page.
comments.author: gamertaboo

comments.text: That's good info. In the second one, he's more interested in flipping the logic, so that driving the board to 0V shuts off the relay, instead of energizing it. I don't see a good reason for that. The schematic they made (still talking about the second one) shows the LED driven by the pin, when dragged down, and the LED would presumably go off when the input is raised high enough that 5V - 3.3V isn't enough to drive the LED. That would actually explain a lot.
comments.author: gamertaboo

comments.text: I didn't have to change any resistors on the relay board. The board is supposedly 5V. If the pi outputs 3.3V, that is usually enough to be considered HIGH on 5V systems. If it doesn't work, you can try wiring in the resistors, or even try powering the relay from 3.3V, which might make the triggering voltage a bit lower.

comments.author: rizkypratama

comments.text:
Yeah this is how i connect my relay (working)
Relay VCC --> VDC 3.3v (Raspi Pin #1)
comments.author: Jeffeb3

comments.text:
If you do this:
Relay VCC -> VDC 3.3V (pi #1)
Relay GND -> GND (pi #6)
Relay IN -> OUT (pi #23)
comments.author: rizkypratama

comments.text: The reason that's working is that the input on the relay is comparing the input to the VCC, so when it's lower, at 3.3V, the input looks higher.
comments.author: Jeffeb3

comments.text: They may not be broken, just configured for a different voltage. The pi outputs 3.3V. Most arduinos use 5V. Using 3.3V with an output is usually ok with 5V devices because 3.3V > 2.5V (the halfway point to 5V). You can confirm this by connecting the relay straight to the 3.3V, GND, and 5V on the pi, and see what states the relay is in.

description.text:
I replaced the clock movement in a cuckoo clock for a friend of mine. The
replacement movement wasn't quite deep enough for the hour hand to fit onto
the pinion without dragging on the clock face. I decided to print a hand with an
extender that would fit properly.

To be sure the hands matched, I also created a matching minute hand. Just for fun
I created a second, standard version of the hour hand without the extender for
anyone who may want a standard set of hands.

CuckooHandHour1 is the standard hour hand
CuckooHandHour2 is the hour hand with the extension
(You only need one of the hour hands, not both)
CuckooHandMinute is the minute hand that matches the hour hands

It turned out very well, see the pictures with the hands installed on a real clock!

This is an easy to build stand for the 7" Raspberry Pi DSI screen. It is meant to be lasercut on 4mm material (MDF for example). It holds the screen at a 30 degree angle.

Cutting instructions:

  • Use the supplied PDF or SVG to lasercut
  • Part 1 is (File with PT1) is needed 2 times
  • Part 2 is needed only one time

Needed parts:

  • Raspberry PI 7" screen (ofcourse)
  • Lasercut parts
  • 4x M3x16 screws
  • Wood glue

Step 1, make sure you get all the parts

Get the parts lasercut (PT1x2) and sand if needed. See needed lasercut parts below

Step 2: Glue the two parts PT1 together

Glue the two parts PT1 together, making sure the are aligned correctly and let the glue dry.

Step 3: Glue PT2 to the two glued PT1 parts

Glue part PT2 to the two glued toghether earlier and let the glue dry

Step 4: Screw screen to backplate

Use the four M3 screws to screw the screen to the backplate

Step 5: Glue the stands to the backplate

Glue the two stands to the backplate aligning them with the notches

description.text: Do you ride clipless pedals but don't like wearing your cleats after a short ride to the store or standing around at a party? Print out some clipless pedal pedals and enjoy a comfortable ride to your next event. These are designed for 2 hole (SPD style) cleats, but could easily be modified for 3 hole. I ride Crank Brothers and it is quite easy to clip these in and out. This part was made with Tinkercad. (https://tinkercad.com/p/acc02218f590e88b/178)

Beware of warping when printing this part. It is very large so it is a problem. A heated build platform is a must basically. 
The bolts are #10-32 x 3/4" or M5 x 20mm round taper, flat head machine screws. Some minor trimming may be needed for the nut receivers. 
Some revisions could be used for better torsional strength in the bolt holes when disengaging the pedal.

description.text:
This is a Solar powered Animatronic Butterfly.
She can be placed on a table top or hung on a wall.
She will flap her wings in the lightest of breezes.
http://youtu.be/J1WN8wXH8_8
The Solar cell circuit is based around a "Miller Engine" , it basically charges up a 1 Farad capacitor and then ports this power in one go to the motor that drives the wings.
This configuration allows her to work in very low light conditions...however she is very active in full sunlight.

Required Solar Miller Engine :-
(search string) SCC3733a-MSE Fast Bundle 1
Required Motor :-
(search string) GM 10 Gear Motor 10 - Geared pager motor The STL files are not orientated for printing , adjust for your printer.
Care should be taken whilst printing the Motor Body Housing (ie use support material)
The Center crank guide need to be cut in the groovy thing. This will allow easy install of the Wing crank center bit.
The Wing cranks need to be trimmed to size to suit...
The wing nubs are used to clamp the wings to the wing cranks.
Print 2 large yelllow spots and 4 small yellow spot - they attach to the wings for giving her that outstanding look.

title: Terracota D-uplo compatible Shingle roof, variable size and shingle tilt

description.text:
Update: Some small bugfixes suggested by @Neon22 have been applied to:
roof_terracotta_EB_mod2.scad. Same Non-commercial license applies

NOTE
DOWLOAD HINGES: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1440521

Terracotta shingle roof roof that can have size and shingle tilt via parameters.
Details can be found on my blog:
http://opengeolog.com/tech/2016/03/23/duplo-compatib…a-shingle-roof/

Settings
Size: The size of the entire build is controlled by two variables lenth and width. The spelling may be not correct but these are their names.
NOTE: use lenth=9; and width=4 as maximum, I experienced some unstable behavior if the variables are set bigger!

Terracotta shingles
This is created by a product of difference of two cylinders. The size, length and pitch of the terracotta singles can be controlled individually. For pitch I used 6 degrees that is set in shingle_tilt variable. The keyword OR stands for outer radius, IR stands for inner, and h is simply the length of the cylinder.

Once you decide to compile it may take quite a while to get an STL file. It will get seemingly stuck at two part somewhere between 60 -70% and 90-100%. Have patience!

Please respect the licence and do NOT use for commercial use under no circumstances. This work is protected by Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International Public License.

Printer:

Prusa i3 homebrew

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

PLA

Notes:

I used a 1.75 PLA (eBay) with .3mm resolution. Base has added support that seemed to be preventing sagging with satisfaction. A block 3x5 printed close to 13hrs!!! on my home made printer. Print quality was pretty decent.
1st and Second Layer, below anti sag supports. Butom anti sag design Shingles on the shingle roof First print 5x3. Took 12h 47mins to print

OpenSCAD instructions:

The design is coded in OpenSCAD and modular.

The only things that need to be modified are lenth and width to set size and shingle_tilt .

Further there is a pretty rich variable section that can be played with and almost anything can be changed and customized. Please change with care. Some parameters were calculated, some measured and implemented and few were determined empirically through experimentation.

Once you decide to compile it may take quite a while to get an STL file. It will get seemingly stuck at two part somewhere between 60 -70% and 90-100%. Have patience!

title: Part for Kenmore clothes washer - Agitation cam "Dog Ear"

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the agitation cam on my Kenmore washer. If your agitator on this model no longer advances, the teeth on this part are probably worn out. I designed this with Taulman Bridge in mind.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aeaw1y8GyHP

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 mm layers / .4 mm nozzle

Infill:

75%+ - need a solid part!

Notes:

You may need to scale the part depending on your printer tolerances and tuning. If the teeth aren't sharp enough, you could shape with a hot razor held by pliers, but mine worked off the bed with the brim torn off.

Use a nylon or plastic intended for mechanical part production. I'm a fan of Bridge nylon.
Print a set of four (or more) at once to allow layers to cool as other pieces are printed.
3 mm brim (Depends on your faith in adhesion...)
255 degree nozzle / 50 degree bed
Nylon dried in oven at 100 F for 2 hours before print.

I used a photo of the part in question, traced into a path in Inkscape and scaled to actual measurements. Saved as a standard .SVG (not Inkscape .SVG) and imported into Tinkercad, extruding to the height of the part. I then used a few primitives to more accurately match the shapes and dimensions.

Sliced in Cura, printed on Octopi.

description.text: Couldn't find one to purchase like I wanted so I made one. Here is my design for a Tofu Press. Tighten it a turn or so every 20 minutes for an hour and even leave it overnight in the fridge if you want to maximize the effect. For anyone who has tried to hand press Tofu or precariously stack all of your cast iron pans on top of a tofu brick will appreciate this kitchen tool.

Finishing

This uses a lot of supports when printed. Although I have a good 1mm clearance around all parts, the excess plastic left behind by the supports required some sanding/melting/grinding to get rid of all of the excess plastic and smooth the surfaces out. Once done, it fit together like a glove so if you're going to tackle this project, make sure you have plenty of finishing tools. If you don't, consider printing the lid and screw just t touch larger (101%?) to ensure there is some slop. Don't change the size of the plate to the box though as it is a close fit with 1mm of tolerance all the way around.

comments.text: NOTE:  Be sure to toughen up the screw.  There is some friction and pressure so a light lube before use and pringint with a heavier fill and thicker walls are good for the impatient.  My first pass whcih was 20% fill and a wall thickness of 3 lasted about 5 jobs and broke under the impatient pressure.  I'm printing the next one at 50 fill and 5 layer walls.  I'll provide feedback after testing.
comments.author: sifugreg

I wanted to insert a colored logo into my rasp pi accessories. there are lots of
cutouts available so I thought I'd post this one

Cheers
Ray

Printer:

Haeckel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For people with dual extruder printers looking to add a colored raspberry pi
image to their prints

I love the amazing work done by MikeyB on designing an open source quadcopter frame, however it was designed for a 20x20 cm build platform which not all printers have. I for my self have a printrbot LC which has a build platform of 15x15cm, so I shrunk his design to fit on such a space. This is the result: the "Crossfire Mini". This thing only contains the modified files. Please also see the original quadcopter "Crossfire" by MikeyB for the rest of the parts, more images, recommendations of electronic parts as well as instructions. The changes I've done are as follows:
  • The arms of this copter are 4.5cm smaller than the original (and printed diagonally), providing a prop-to-prop distance of only 39.5cm on the diagonal (instead of about 48cm). It's enough for 9" props at most.
  • The top plate carries the receiver; since this holder exceeded the print volume, I moved it more towards the center and cut off the end which is now a separate part to be screwed together (the same screws from the original design). If you modify it to fit your Rx exactly, it will nicely hold it with no zip tie or glue required.
  • This design currently has neither a direct camera mount nor holes for bushings to add the "Vibration Dampening Camera Mount" also designed by MikeyB. Add them to your needs if you want to use FPV.
    • I modified the meshes of MikeyB's original design directly and only upload them. For the original SketchUp files, see the original Crossfire. If you don't like the idea of having landing gears directly on the arm ends, see my Landing Gears for Crossfire, which is compatible with both the original Crossfire as well as this mini version.

comments.text: Hey,
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hey! In the meanwhile I was able to fly it. It's my first copter so I have no comparison. It flew quite good in my opinion; thanks to the KK2.0 auto level feature it was very stable in the air, although I didn't calibrate it. I am now also confident that it should be possible to add a camera. I use Turnigy Aerodrive SK3 - 2826-1240kv motors together with 25Amp ESCs and a 3S lipo. My quad has a total weight of 1050 g (incl. battery). With this setup I can hold the altitude with approx. 45% throttle, which results in a maximum upward acceleration of about the free fall acceleration (= 10 m/s²). For good experiences it's recommended to have more power (altitude hold throttle being about 33% which results in twice maximum upward acceleration). I'm very satisfied and for a beginner like me this is definitely enough to start with. Summarizing, I think you should definitely give it a try! Hope this helps! ;)
Nice, you added some led stripes around the body! Perfect for nightfligt! Do you have different colors to know whats front and back?

PS. the stripes are from hobbyking, search for waterproof LED. They are quite cheap and connect directly to a 3S battery since they are rated for 12V (you can connect them to 4S with a regulator in between).

title: Adafruit IoT Pi Printer Project Pack - Enclosure

description.text:
Adafruit IoT Pi Printer Project Pack - Enclosure http://www.adafruit.com/products/1289 Adafruit invests time and resources providing this open source design, please support Adafruit and open-source hardware by purchasing products from Adafruit! Build an "Internet of Things" connected mini printer that will do your bidding! This is a fun weekend project that comes with a beautiful laser cut case. Once assembled, the little printer connects wirelessly to get Internet data for printing onto 2 1/4" wide receipt paper. Based on a Raspberry Pi computer, this is a powerful mini Linux machine. We have example python code for a few different printouts including a daily weather forecast report, sudoku puzzles, image printer and a tweeter printer that connects Twitter's search API and retrieve and print tweets according to your requests: you can have it print out tweets from a person, a hashtag, mentioning a word, etc! All the code is open source so its easy to adapt and write your own custom printer software

  • These files are for the laser cut enclosure for the project, a new version for the Raspberry Pi!

  • For the cut out files for our IoT Printer built around the Arduino, see this Thing here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18319
    • Complete assembly instructions available at Adafruit:
    http://learn.adafruit.com/pi-thermal-printer/ Designed by Adafruit Industries.
    Creative Commons, Attribution & Share-Alike license
    All text above must be included in any redistribution

Use 3mm acrylic sheet, 10 #4-40 screws (1/2 inch), and 10 hexnuts to assemble this enclosure. A pair of small ~5mm stand-offs can be used to lift the Raspberry Pi off the acrylic, or you can 3D print them.

title: ROBO 3D HD Side Mount Spool Holder w/ Snag Compensator, Alignment Pulley

description.text:
Update 5-1-16
Added solid models

Wanted to make a new heavy duty design for a spool holder that took care of a few things. My old holder was kinda flopping around front to back and it seemed towards the end of the roll I would encounter more snags as the filament was fed side to side. I decided to make a mount that fed the filament from the side at a better angle, more inline. I also added a compensation pulley that allows the filament to be fed higher to achieve a better angle down; the springs allow you to buy some time before a snag becomes a detriment. The compensation pulley rides in a needle bearing, it's tight, I found that it spins best (surprisingly well) if only half the needles are used and some of that tube lube, this may just be my machine tolerances though. The spool holder is designed to be an easier lift off while still adding structural integrity, spool plugs are included. I made the tolerances on the tight side so there may be some massaging of parts to your liking, just didn't want to make them too loose.

The model components require no glue, screws, or overhangs...everything snaps into place and to each other and uses the contours of the ROBO case for support. I've included two pairs of sides, one for the spring and one without the spring. To assemble insert slit pin "grab" into far left side of the slit on top of the ROBO, assemble bottom sections and snap them in place. Attach springs to notched xbrace, slide upper brace though springs, pulley and guide then attach sides. Once this is assembled slide into the mounting holes on the two bottom sections.....
**Note...in the pic looking into the holder you'll notice the back side is shorter, this was a mistake on my part during the design changing process, it has been corrected to be the same size as the front...

CHALLENGE

This is a wip to an extent of 90% of my vision. Ultimately here's what I'd like to add that is a little above me at this point. I would like to put two position sensors on the back side...one that senses minor deflection and one that senses major deflection that interface with the pulley bar. The sensors will connect to the brain on this to alter some run conditions. The first sensor being tripped will enable a run condition of 50% feed and 50% speed and will also create an alert being an alarm, flashing light, etc. The second sensor (max deflection) will pause the print, do a minimum filament retraction and kill the hot end.

If anybody can pull this off I'll PayPal 20.00. I know it's not a lot but I hope the challenge will make up for it...Thanks...

title: FrSky D8R-II Plus NO TUBE Antenna Holder Mount

description.text:
The 2 beauties of this antenna holder are:
A) You WON'T have to buy antenna tubes. Instead, it holds regular, cheap ZIP TIEs that you can find just about anywhere.
B) The ZIP TIE is mounted so it can flop back and forth, but not sideways. This means that your antenna can bend in a crash, without hitting the propellers!! See one of the pictures that shows the antenna being bent.

This was made for the FrSky D8R-II Plus, but you can easily modify it for other receivers/transceivers.

The 2 top holes are just peep holes to help guide you when routing the antenna wires and when attaching the receiver to the antenna holder. I use regular Velcro to hold my receiver and this antenna holder assembly.

Many hours of flying (and crashes) and it works like a champ!

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Form 1

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 microns

Notes:

Install the ZIP TIEs before installing the antenna wires.

Instead of using little ZIP TIEs to hold the antenna wire to the big ZIP TIE, you can use shrink-tubes to hold the antenna wires.
If using an UV curable resin (e.g., Form1 printers), it is highly recommended that you paint the part to protect it from direct sunlight. Otherwise the part may become brittle and break.

No more whacked antennae?

I just got tired of having my antennae chopped up, and I didn't want to spend more money on antenna tubes, when I already have a ton of ZIP TIEs laying around.

remixed_from.title: Replicator 2 Top Mount Filament Spool Holder/Dispenser

description.text: These parts upgrade your Spool Holder/Dispenser http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74050 it raises your spools up enough for your wires to clear. The spool-supports evens out the odd sized holes of your spools and keeps them spinning freely. This upgrade allows you to use a 1/2" rod or tubing instead of the all-thread, eliminating your spools from walking. I have about 20hr of trouble free printing with this modification.

I printed these parts using the standard setting with 2 shells and 5% infill on a raft with supports.
-Remove supports and slide over the top of the Spool Holder Dispenser tops, I added the option to expand forward if you like (not tested).
-Pop the spool supports in the spools (only tested on MBI spools) and slide them over your 1/2" rod. I used 1/2" stainless steel tubing because I had it laying around. I also added some 1/2" locking collars from McMaster I would use http://www.mcmaster.com/#1511k12/=oagvzm because they are cool, you could even print some caps that would prevent it from sliding off if you bumped into it.

title: Borg Station 8 - An M Prime One Remix

description.text:
This is my customized version of the M Prime One by Diego. I used his base design and a few things I liked about some other 3D printers, such as the ability to tension the X and Y axis belts using a screw. The base and frame positioning allow for the ramps board to be placed behind the print bed with access to the LCD screen on top. This is a similar setup to the funbot. These are just a few of the changes.

I have included a PDF which lists the parts/hardware needed and provides some guidance via pictures on how to assemble it. I have been able to print at 100 microns at 25mm/sec and the prints come out very nice.

title: Blue sky crystals ("Breaking Bad" inspired prop)

description.text: Printed in icicle blue PLA, this plate of crystalline randomness bears a passing resemblance to the iconic prop crystals used on that popular beardy meth guy show the kids these days seem to like. This is intended as a toy for fans of a fictional TV show. Due to my strong personal convictions, I wish to stress that this published thing in no way endorses actual drug use or drug culture.

Try a few different slicing methods, and find what gives you the best results with your printer and filament:
  • 3 shells and 0% infill for pale, light, quick-printing hollow crystals
  • 1 shell and 100% infill for solid, more deeply hued crystals
  • 30 shells and 0% infill for solid crystals with a more interesting crystalline grain inside (I like this method, and used it for the prints shown above)
    • If you use MakerWare, the .thing file posted here will allow you to add, subtract, scale, and rearrange individual crystals on the build plate. Rescale the model randomly and reprint to add some more variety. Do not smoke.

description.text:
I needed a place to mount an aftermarket fuel pressure regulator in my Subaru Legacy GT, so I installed a strut brace and printed this bracket. You can find these strut braces on ebay from a few different vendors for about $50 in raw aluminum or $100 with a carbon fiber wrap.

Note that the bracket is actually sized for a strut brace that is wrapped in carbon fiber (yay bling!) but it works well enough on the raw aluminum brace as well.

If you have a raw aluminum bar and want a tight fit, feel free to tweak the .scad file and upload your version. I apologize in advance for the messy scad.

The center section, used to mount the fuel pressure regulator, should be considered a starting point for brackets for other things. Feel free to customize that one too. And I apologize even more for the even more messy scad.

A modular LED flower bracelet. The flower is attached to the bracelet base via metal snaps, which are also part of the circuit.

One lead of the LED passes through the center of the flower and is soldered to the snap there, and the other goes through the side of the flower and through the center of the leaf. The leaf has a whole on the bottom so the snap can be soldered to the wire as part of the circuit. On the top of the band there is an indentation with another snap where the leaf can be snapped in place, completing the circuit and lighting up the LED. So the leaf acts as the switch.

A CR2032 3V battery (you can find them at the dollar store) is stored inside the band, and is covered up by a plastic cover which is also attached via snaps. The bracelet has slits on either side to allow you to attach a band. In this case I used lace. Due to the modular design you could design your own light up attachment and add it to the bracelet via snaps.

title: Place Marks... Mark Pages and Places on the Pages

description.text:
Place Marks aren't just Book Marks...use them to mark pages as well as content / areas on those pages. They are handy for marking places in story books, manuals and guides, on timetables and recipe books. Use several at a time in the one book to make it quick and easy to find common or necessary content... and always be able to continue reading your story from where you last stopped reading.

Simple slide your page mark in place over several pages so they are secure enough to hold in place but not overly tight (as that could damage your pages). The number of pages required to achieve this will vary from book due to differing thicknesses of pages etc.

Place Marks are very small and super easy prints that use very little filament. Print a few when you have a small amount of filament left at the end of a spool and use them yourself or as small gifts.

There are three sizes available to cover almost every application. Medium size is the most common as it covers the broadest range of uses. Print in your colour/s of choice. You may also want to use different colours as a form of index for specific related content.. And, if you've previously been using loads of little stickers to do this you'll save money as well.

Please refer to the images and print setting for additional information.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

title: Supports for Prusa i3 aluminium frame

description.text:
Supports for Prusa i3's aluminium frame.
Goes well with my spool holder, since it adds weight on top of the frame, which may cause some wobbling around.

At the default settings, the new support rods have to be 386mm, or let's say ~390mm long.
Also you need to swap the threaded rods at the end of the Y-axis to 370mm long ones.

So you'll need:
2x 390mm M8 threaded rods (Make sure and measure how long ones you actually need).
2x 370mm M8 threaded rods.
16x M8 nuts.
16x M8 washers.
2x at least 20mm M3 screws to replace the old M3 screws from the upper z-axis smooth rod holder.

Tell me if there's some options you'd like to see added to the customizer.
Or if there's something that behaves silly.

designed by solidworks

These are non-functional objects based on the Liberator gun by Defense Distributed. These models are fused together, and the original geometry and mechanisms can not be recovered or easily reverse engineered from the files here. Again: while these objects vaguely resemble weapons, they cannot be used as weapons any more than any other 3d print. This project borrows an idea from One coffee cup a day, producing several absurd variations on the original Liberator file. Hopefully, they should make people feel like there's nothing sacred or singular about "that 3d printed gun file" but that it's something that can be remixed, appropriated, redirected, repurposed. That it's not just "floating around out there", or in the hands of a few people, that's it's not something to be feared, but treated critically, carefully, humorously, seriously. For more information see the post on the F.A.T. Lab Blog or Andy Greenberg's Forbes article. If you'd like to make your own variations, start with the "original-fused.stl" which is an assembled, to scale, non-functional Liberator.

Two of the files were produced in Mesh Lab and are distributed here as .stl files, the rest were produced in Rhino. Some of these are watertight and could be printed, others have problematic geometry and would have to be processed significantly before being printable.

print_settings.Notes:: Please rotate the objects by 90 degree on the y axis

description.text:
This is a chinese 3D puzzle as I remember to have played when I was child. I don't know the story of this puzzle or if it is really a chinese one, but I know that with these three pieces you'll be astonished to see with how much difficulty people will assemble the figure! They'll think "hey, three pieces! That should be so easy!"... but when they have the three pieces in hands they struggle to understand how to insert them!
Try it by yourself :) This will be a wonderful conversation starter...

I designed these pieces so that they should be easy and fast to print, without any support.

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm layer

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Please rotate the objects by 90 degree on the y axis before you print it, they must lay flat on the printing bed! I used Fusion 360 at the standard settings with inverted z/y axis...
I calibrated the clearance between interlocking parts so that it should be right using a New Matter MOD-t at the standard Cura profile speed. If you have a well calibrated printer maybe the pieces will be a little loose but that will work for sure.
If you need to much force to insert the pieces sand it a little, particularly on the edge.
I inserted a chamfer on the base of the print to reduce the first layer little border that would have prevented correct interlocking.
Print of these pieces is fast and easy!

description.text:
This is my first Thingiverse upload! I decided to make this since it only includes a bag (pfft I dont care about dust when it could snap in my backpack!!)
I have yet to create it my self as my makerbot thing-o-matic still hasn't arrived :(
I printed a 1:1 ratio diagram of the headphone slot to make sure that the headphones would fit.
Im not sure if the clip will snap off since I haven't been able to experiment with the plastics flexibility yet ( still haven't made my first print!)
The case and cover are too big to print as a whole on a makerbot, and I wont be making them into split parts until my makerbot arrives.
I decided to upload the files either way for now in case anybody wants to use them with a bigger printer, or split the parts themselves and super glue them.
These parts were made on Autodesk Inventor. If anybody would like me to upload those files as well to modify them just let me know. I have yet to print this myself so it will still be a work in progress!! But if anybody else prints it to try it out, I'd love feedback! Oh and I also added the makerbot logo on the front :) Update:
I'm uploading the split case and cover parts. The names are Cover_1, Cover_2, etc... If your going to build this on a printer that doesnt have a big enough build area for the whole pare, dont use the Cover.stl, use the ones I just described instead.
The cover and the case have been split into 9 parts each.

Update:
I will not be updating this part due to time and schoolwork so it is incomplete atm. I will still leave it here for those who wish to have access to the files for any particular reason. All parts are 3D printed. Super glue will be required.
The axle should be printed twice (two are needed)
Place the cover on top of the case, and insert each axle in the holes where the cover rotates around. Super glue the ends of each axle to keep them in place, but make sure not to let the glue seep through to the cover so that is can still rotate freely! Update:
If printing the split up cover and case, set super glue these parts together (based on the item images) and hold them together on a flat surface to make sure theyre even.

remixed_from.author: AtomKemp
remixed_from.title: Super Compact Pan Tilt Camera Mount

title: pan tilt remix uses ES08MA 9g servos

description.text:
I modified the original files using Sketchup, after printing i drilled out the holes to match the servo holes, with a 1/16 drill bit. i used the circular servo attachments and mounted with #2x1/4 screws for the servos and #2x1/2 for the pivot for the camera arm. holds a standard board cam, with number 2 metric screws.
The completed picture is of a previous revision then the files uploaded here, i slimmed down the base and raised the horizontal servo. I have not got this mounted on my plane yet, but it works great on the bench.
Today i added a bunch of pictures to help anyone who may have trouble putting this thing together. After you get the idea it's not too bad.
1) clean up your print, if you need to. (file, sand, etc.)
2) drill out the holes for the servo attachment screws, and install the screws that come with the servo. I used a 1/16 bit.
3) mount the brackets to the 'ring'
4) glue the brackets to the ring, I used superglue, works well for me, I use the steam from my espresso maker to wet the PLA before I apply the super glue, which as i understand it makes the superglue set up much quicker.
5) drill out the holes on the servo round servo horn for the bottom/ horizontal servo. just use 2 that align with the holes in the base. i installed the screws from the top, but this does leave screw tips that hang out the bottom. if that is a problem trim your screws before you install them, or file the excess screw points off after the install. Make sure the splines on the servo horn face the servo!
6) Drill out the round servo horn for the camera tilt bracket. I install the screws from the outside through the PLA and into the servo horn. Make sure the splines on the servo horn face the servo!
7) Pre-drill the PLA for the pivot on the camera bracket, make sure to over drill the bracket it's self, as this is the pivot on the screw. ( I have not installed this screw yet on either of my pan tilt assemblies, as it's very easy to take the thing apart as long as it's not installed.
8) center your servo's and press the servos on to the servo horns and install the remaining screw that holds the servo to the horn.

I hope this helps someone, and I want to give a shout out to the original designer, AtomKemp, for the great work.

I'm working on a protective cover for the camera, it's not done yet, but you can see the prototype in one of my pictures.
this thing printed in PLA with my settings weighs in at 60 grams.

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a crush-able/throw-able Easter egg that has flower seed and potting mix in it. With Easter fast approaching I wanted to come up with a great gift to give to friends and family.

This has been printed with TWOBEARS Biofila Linen. The filament is a very biodegradable and natural. It is made from linen, a complex polymer of aromatic alcohols known as monolignols. Linen is found in the secondary cell walls of plants and some algae. So you can leave it on the ground after throwing or crushing the eggs.

Any seeds will work, in this case I used hummingbird and butterfly wildflower mix

Notes:

You will need ample cooling to keep the sides from curling. Also print a little slower then you may normally. It is best to print more then one at a time so you let the layers cool. I printed them with a 20 line brim to hold the eggs upright while printing.

At about 50% though the print throw soil in the eggs then some seeds. At the 75% mark you can add more potting soil. Some people may find it appalling to throw soil on there expensive 3D printer. I understand this, You could also simply have eggs that kids can color later. Try filling them with candy, or a flashing LED.
Trim and sand as necessary then color with markers

title: FatShark Pilot HD V2 mount for ZMR250 Frame (V2 PDB)

description.text:
Mount for the FatShark Pilot HD V2 to the ZMR250 frame from FPVModel (with the V2 PDB).

The bottom shell fits in the square hole in the Power Distribution Board and positions the camera at an 11.8 degree angle (just the way the trigonometry worked out). The top bracket fits into the front two Mobius mount holes. I used two layers of 3M Scotch foam tape on the top bracket to hold the camera firmly. Two small strips of foam tape keep the bottom shell in place over the hot glue.

Mount positions the camera behind the front edge of the ZMR250 frame so you wont damage your camera in a head-on collision.

The camera view is clear with none of the quad in the shot.

If you carefully file the center slot wider, you can get the micro SD card in and out without taking apart the quad after every flight. Be careful with Carbon fiber dust, it's conductive.

author: alanbly

title: Multi-layer acrylic trophies (intended to explain the underlying principle)

description.text:
I made these for the Australian Warhammer 40K Masters tournament, hosted by Good Games in Canberra:
http://www.wargamerau.com/forum/index.php?showtopic=85153&pid=1156717&mode=threaded&show=&st=&#entry1156717 The construction process may be of use and interest to Thingiverse members so I'll share it here. The trophies are made from multiple thicknesses held together without glue, by 3mm cut "rods" through "gripping holes", bordered with "finger clamps" to keep the rods in place.

The process is as follows (bit of a long read but the underlying principle is easy):

  • Vectorize the art.

  • Decide how many acrylic and trophy plate layers you will divide the piece into, and what will be on each layer. For example in the case of the dragon, from front to back the layers are:
    • 2a. Silver trophy plate, engraved with the descriptive text (at the client's request I cut a rectangular section out where the name goes and supplied him with the names on plates cut to fit; he applied the names of winner, runner-up and best sportsman to the appropriate trophies himself). 2b through 2c. 3mm acrylic rectangles for the base. Stack as many of these as are required to make a stable block to support the piece upright. In this case there are three of them, and it may still be just a bit narrow. 2d. Silver trophy plate, engraved with the art of the dragon. Holes are left for the eyes and the nostrils. 2e. 3mm acrylic outline of the dragon's body. Holes with tabs are cut for the eyes and nostrils; these are cut separately from 3mm orange acrylic and inserted. The trophy plate at 2d covers the tabs and holds the eyes and nostrils in place. 2f. Same as 2e, with second layer for eyes (acrylic mirror) and nostrils (red acrylic). This layer's outline is extended via a rectangular stem to the base as well. 2g. 3mm acrylic outline of the dragon's body, stem and base. A hole with tabs is cut for the outer layer of the flame, which is separately cut from orange acrylic and inserted. 2h (centre). 3mm acrylic outline of the dragon's body, stem and base. A hole with tabs is cut for the centre layer of the flame, which is separately cut from red acrylic and inserted. 2i. Reflection of 2g. 2j. Reflection of 2f. Note that the facing direction of the acrylic mirror eye is reversed. 2k. Reflection of 2e. 2l. Reflection of 2d. 2m through 2o. 3mm acrylic rectangles for the base. Note that if you centre the rods through these properly you can make them up identically to 2b; I didn't do this and had a bit of trouble with it, as CorelDraw was centring the holes across the entire piece, not just the base piece. Create a separate rectangle over the base rectangle, centre with that, then delete the sizing rectangle. 2p. Silver trophy plate for the back of the base. My logo's on this, not shown in the photo.

  • Having worked the plan out (it's a lot less complex than it appears from the above exhaustive list), for each layer, create a new CorelDraw page, cut and paste the outlines and the relevant parts of the piece. Rename each layer with its material type, eg "3mm clear", "silver plate".

  • Layers past the middle do not actually need to be mirror-flipped. Only the outermost layer of silver trophy plate on the dragon's body, and the mirror insert for its left eye, actually needed to be mirror-flipped (This is a bit of a mind-bender!) You may want to mirror-flip the inserts, especially the orange bits for eye and nostril, if you get a better-quality finish on one side of your acrylic. (As an aside, one of the advantages of this process is that you don't need to worry about fingerprints, or much about melted acrylic getting deposited on the surface of layers; it's all stuck together and covered with trophy plate. There's about five square centimetres of the thing that is visibly bare acrylic.)

  • Create your rectangular support rods. These will need to run through all acrylic layers, and their ends will be covered by the trophy plate. They therefore need to be 3mm x (number of layers) long, and 3mm wide. Obviously, adjust these dimensions if you're using 1/8" acrylic or indeed any other thickness of acrylic. As some of the parts of the piece have different numbers of layers (eg the base), the rods in those parts will need to be longer or shorter accordingly. It doesn't really matter which layer you put your rods on but I found that it helps a bit to make them all on the same layer, but to leave a decent gap between each and between them and other cut lines, to keep any acrylic bending from heat to an absolute minimum.

  • Create your support holes to run the rods through. You can use holes a little too big on internal layers (ie a 3.2mm x 3.2mm hole), which will make it easier to fit the piece together over the rods. Or you can just make gripping holes all through.
    • 6a. A gripping hole has the following structure, like an hourglass: |-[]-| That's a line about 1mm to the side of the hole that runs the length of the hole, a tiny line in the middle to join the previous line to the hole, the hole itself which is just a teensy bit smaller than it should be to let the rod through, another joining line, and another side line. This has the effect of making very slightly flexible "fingers" which will tightly grip the rods. Ideally you will need to exert some pressure to get the rod into the hole; it may even break with a crunch as you do so. This is fine; the broken bits jam the hole, holding the rod in. Ideally it should not come out ever again. 6b. I can't stress this enough: master this first. Make up practice gripping holes and rods from offcut acrylic. While the net effect of gripping holes is to give much wider tolerance for interlocking acrylic pieces, the exact dimensions of them will vary depending on the kerf of the laser, the thickness of the acrylic (which does vary enough from sheet to sheet to make a difference), how exactly focussed your laser is, etc. You may find it best to try out a few different sizes at once, eg make up holes between 2.8mm and 3.2mm with 0.05mm gradations, and try fitting a rod into each to discover which has the best fit.

  • Group up the holes, then copy and paste them to all relevant layers. You need to visualize the pages as the third dimension of the piece. Holes must be in exactly the same place on each layer.

  • Create extra separate pages for inserted materials (eg acrylic mirror, red acrylic, orange acrylic). Copy and paste the cut outlines for these, from the layers in which they are to be inserted. If you're running holes through inserted materials make sure you copy these too.

  • Save a copy of the file created in this "3D exploded view", one layer per page, everything in its correct final position. This will make re-sizing infinitely easier, if you want to create first/second/third etc variations. Note that if you re-size the piece itself, you will need to keep the holes the same size and reposition them. This is most easily done by grouping up the holes in step 7, then when you need to resize, delete all but one from all layers, resize the piece, then reposition the holes from scratch.

  • Group layers, then cut and paste and nest them such that the minimum amount of material is used. You may want to print them at the minimum size to the laser, and use your laser's software to organize them onto the actual sheets; on the other hand if there's a lot of gaps, such as between the dragon's wing and its tail, and your laser isn't capable of non-rectangular nesting, it may be more efficient to do it manually. Or you can use a nesting plugin or separate program. Or skip this step entirely and make a pile of offcut acrylic to use in other projects. It's your workshop. :D

  • Having gotten the pieces off the laser, peel the paper and lay them out. This is the 3D jigsaw puzzle section of the build. I found it helped to firstly stick the trophy plate to the outermost two layers, as the sticky plate helped keep the rods stable. Pick one of the outermost layers and place all of your rods in it. You may need to force them, as discussed at 6 above; do not be unduly concerned if you get "crunching", especially if you've cut "gripping holes" throughout the piece. Next, put the layers onto the rods, bit by bit. This is the most fiddly part of the whole process and I'd recommend cutting some gripping holes and rods out of offcut acrylic to practice with before you move to assembling the piece itself. If you have significant trouble with a hole just snap a finger or two; you can afford to do that here and there and not compromise the stability of the piece, and as the holes are hidden and internal, no-one will ever notice.
    • Good luck with it! :D This ended up being a lot more exhaustive than I'd first intended; really the whole thing evolves from the rod vs "gripping hole" dynamic. If you plan to do this it'd be best to select some art for yourself and follow the steps above. As noted at 6b making gripping holes with your individual acrylic sheet and laser may require some fiddling with the sizes, so just running my files off directly may not actually work for you. Email at [email protected] if you need any advice, but bear in mind that I thought this up a week ago and have spent, oh, maybe five hours total with it, so you haven't got far to go to get better at it than me. I'm definitely interested in seeing things you've made with it. :D

title: Finger/thumb assembly jig for an e-NABLE Phoenix prosthetic hand

description.text: This jig is intended to make the assembly of the fingers and thumb of an e-NABLE Phoenix hand easier for novice makers especially during an assembly event. It can also assist people with only one fully functional hand to assemble one of these assistive devices. It holds the finger/thumb tip in alignment with the proximal phalanges (also referred to as a phalanx) so that a snap pin can be pushed or driven in to join them.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folger RepRap 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Although separate STL files are provided for different hand scale factors between 100% and 150% in 5% increments this only provides different text to mark the size. The STL should be scaled up using your slicer when printing at a scale larger than 100%.
The text on the jig can be made easier to read if the first few layers are printed in a contrasting color to the upper layers. When printed at 100% all the text begins at a height of 1mm. When scaling larger than 100% you'll need to scale up the height of the first color section. For example, when scaling at 130% the filament should be changed at the first layer above 1.3mm .

comments.text: The STL didn't like the Prusa version of Slic3r.   Came in as an incomplete object.   Simplify 3D brought it in no problem but since I use the MMU upgrade on my Prusa I prefer to use the Slic3R software.    I uploaded the file to Makeprintable.com and it repaired it and it works flawlessly in Slic3r now.  I am more than happy to provide you with the fixed STL if you want (or anyone else)

description.text: This is a mount that I created to attach the BLTouch probing sensor to my Ord Bot Hadron with Bulldog XL extruder and E3D V6 hot end. It attaches to the back side of the X-Carriage using M2.5 screws through the standard mounting holes on the back side of the plate. The BLTouch probe works great and was very easy to set-up connecting to RAMBo board's MX1 header and Z-min endstop.

Clean up holes and mount BLTouch with wires facing away from X-Carriage. Route wires across the top and through mounting bracket to go underneath X-Carriage plate and back up through large hole on the bottom side of the plate.

remixed_from.author: DrazzticAction
remixed_from.title: Ninjaflex Drive Mod for Mk8 V7 Extruder upgrade

title: PrintRite DIY Printer Ninjaflex Drive Modification

description.text:
Modified this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:788358 to work on the PrintRite DIY 3D Printer. After printing in ABS with 100% infill, you'll need to file (or cut with an X-acto blade) some grooves in the main plate next to the lower filament hole to allow the idler wheel to get close enough to pinch the filament against the drive wheel and turn freely. You will also need to remove the original plastic cap on top of the extruder heater tube and adjust the heater tube height to mate up to the bottom of the printed extruder base plate.

Depending on how well tuned your printer is, you may need to clean up and size the holes for a good fit with drill bits.

Edit: I forgot to mention earlier that I ended up drilling out a relief on the back of the heatsink to make room for the idler bearing screw head. I also ground the head of the idler bearing screw down a little bit thinner. I really should have posted this right after making it so I could remember exactly what I did!

Tested and works well with NinjaFlex. The last photo in the gallery above shows a tire made in NinjaFlex on my printer on an ABS wheel. This is part of another "thing" I'm working on that I'll share when I finish it up.

Disclaimer- It has been a couple of months since I made this, and it took me a while to find the STL files again to post. It is possible that what I uploaded isn't the exact revision of the base plate I ended up using, although I believe it is... Let me know if something simply doesn't fit right, especially the depth of the hole for the round shoulder on the extruder stepper motor around the shaft.

comments.text:
I made one, and with just a little modification no need to cut the aluminium part...
It's working really great, it's really, REALLY esay to change the filament :D
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
Not having had anything to do with Ninjaflex, I was wondering, is it just a case of adding better support for the filament to stop it from bending or flexing? As there's hardly a significant difference between the original setup and this setup, enough to stop it working I suppose.
So is it only a case of making sure the Ninjaflex (probably a better name than rubbery stuff!) is guided as much along it's length as possible?
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: NinjaFlex can't tolerate an unsupported gap between the output of the extruder drive and the heater tube because it is so flexible. It would fold over under the extrusion pressure and bind up.   This modification allows the filament to be supported almost all the way up to where the drive wheel and the idler meet.   It is still completely compatible with stiffer filaments after the modification.   The photo I posted shows green ABS in the extruder
comments.author: hughee

title: Basic ESC Cover for KISS 24a and others

description.text:
Designed a super basic ESC cover because I chopped my signal wires in a crash so I figured this would be a little better. Some have been designed with tabs or whatnot to clip it into place. Crashes are unpredictable. I recommend taping this down with either electrical tape or some self-sealing tape or even just use heatshrink around it. I made it slightly bigger than the KISS 24a ESC's that I put on an X-Labs Shrike. Hope this is useful for someone.

Printed in TPU. Can use other filaments but the rubbery and absorption properties of TPU seems best to me.

UPDATED: Added some vents on one side of the ESC where your FETs are to help give them some airflow. The majority of the heat is generated from the FETs and once air hits them it will disperse through the front and rear openings depending on how you mount it.

title: Ezra Bridger's Lightsaber
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My kids and I are big Star Wars Rebels fans. There are many lightsabers on Thingiverse but I was surprised not to find this one. So...this is my rendition of Ezra Bridger's lightsaber.

This is a sizable project, with at least 25 parts (depending on configuration), and measuring about 9.25" x 5.5". The silver clip in the front is removable, per my son's request, and fastens with two 8mm magnets located in the bridge at the bottom. I have also included a peg to print if you choose to forgo the magnets and permenantly attach the clip. The tolerances and pretty tight between the pieces, so all the parts should fit nice and snug.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

For parts like the emitter and hilt grip, there are both assembled and individual peices supplied. Supports are required if you are printing the assembled versions.

There are a few parts that will require supports. For the most part, supports are only needed for interior faces and don't interfere with exterior surfaces.

back-block-bottom,
blaster-body,
blaster-clip-to-bridge,
blaster-fastner,
emitter-assembly,
hilt-bridge,
hilt-handle-assembly,
hilt-trigger-housing,

print_settings.Notes:: An infill of 30% is good.  The better the resolution, the better the quality on your finished product.

description.text:
This mold was created to repair a set of headphones that had a broken connection at the point where each earbud met the main wire.

Once the damaged connection is repaired, print out this mold and cast a new one from SUGRU.

If you've never played with Sugru, go check out their videos. It's a siliconized rubber that you can mold like a putty, but it cures overnight into an extremely durable rubber overnight.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

30%

Notes:

An infill of 30% is good. The better the resolution, the better the quality on your finished product.

HOW-TO

Materials:

  • Sugru
  • petroleum jelly, vegetable oil, shortening, etc.
  • Headphones
  • Bolts (M3x30 work well for this mold)
  • Busted Headphones
  • Small clamp (optional)

Procedure:

  1. Cut away the damaged segments of wire with good, sharp snips
  2. Carefully solder the wires back together. Most headphone wires are enameled and very difficult to solder. I have had great success by making a solder "pot" from a large blob of molten solder.
    a. Melt a large blob of solder with your iron (I heated my Weller unit to ~700C)
    b. Dip each bundle of enameled wire into the molten blob until the enamel begins to boil and burn off.
  3. Test! Make sure they work before you move forward. Make sure there are no shorts and that the solder joints are good.
  4. Use a bit of hot-melt glue to insulate the soldered strands. This will keep them electrically isolated and provide some mechanical strength.
  5. Measure up your blob of wire, cable thickness and customize and print the mold. The default settings worked well for cloth coated, 4 conductor wire for earbuds. YMMV.
  6. Clean up the mold with a file and sand paper and make sure it fits together well. Wash it well to remove any dust.
  7. Coat the inside of the mold with a thin layer of petroleum jelly, vegetable shortening or vegetable oil - this will act as a release. Coat the flat faces of the mold too. Sugru is pretty good at sticking to stuff that isn't coated.
  8. WASH YOUR HANDS. Sugur hates fats and oils. If you fold oil into your connector it will fall apart.
  9. Insert the guide bolts
    . Knead the sugru and warm it up. Form it into the rough shape of the Y-Mold. Use a bit more sugru than you think you need to make sure the mold is well filled.
  10. Insert the rough form into the mold. Close the mold up using the guide bolts to align and press hard using a clamp or your hands.
  11. Count to 10 while pressing.
  12. Carefully pull apart the halves and gently remove the Y connector from the mold. Try not to touch it too much. If you foul this up, you can try to push the two halves back together and fix your mistakes.
  13. Hang it to cure over the next 24-48 hours. Longer curing is recommended as the central sphere is quite large.
  14. After it has cured, use a hobby knife to clean up any of the flash that squeezed out between the two mold halves.

comments.text: I had an idea that could be a "spinoff" of this.  What if you make some molds with five and six entry ways on them, and a central ball where the Sugru could be, then put bamboo or cane in the entry ways, so you could make joints for a Geodesic dome?

title: Stokke Tripp Trapp adapter for new extended glider on old chair

description.text:
This simple adapter can be mounted to older Stokkes Tripp Trapp baby chairs fabricated until 2013. This allows to mount the extended gliders, which are needed to increase safety.

The factory gliders for the older chairs are currently out of stock, so if you want to buy a used chair and plan to upgrade it with a new baby seat, your only option is a DIY solution.

The adapter is mounted to the chair with a 4.5 x 50mm wood screw and the glider that comes with the new baby seats can be snapped into place.

I would recommend printing at 100% infill and to check for structural integrity before use.

If you have no idea what I am talking about, you will propably not need this thing ;)

comments.text: Hi, thank you for making this! I knew the 3d printing community would come thru for me when Stokke told me they no longer sell the gliders for older chairs. :) I'm ordering this to be printed thru one of the apps. Can you confirm:
comments.author: elizabeth_

comments.text:
Hi, thanks :)
currently I don't think you need 100% fill factor anymore, 50% will probably do fine. I would print it with 200µm layer height, the thing will not be more stable with 100µm layers.
ABS is probably the right choice.

description.text:
this is a pellet seating tool for .177 cal break barrel style air rifles. insert the pellet in the breach as usual, use the 'nipple' end to push the pellet in and it should slightly flair out the skirt of the pellet in the breach so it is just a hair bigger than the bore, then use the pin end of the tool to push the pellet 1 or 2 millimeters into the bore, this should compress the slightly flared skirt and form it to the exact bore size, lock it into the rifling and give it a perfect seal

title: $65 3D printer made from recycled electronic waste

description.text:
Our goal is to provide enough information to enable people to build low cost 3D printers from electronic waste and also keep potential 3D printers out of land fill.

Please check out video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YkrMPGtMW3M

I am working with Substation33 (non for profit social enterprise in Brisbane Australia).
We currently provide 3D printers to high schools, do our best to help the disadvantaged here in Brisbane, recycle e-waste, and up-cycle what we can into useful/interesting projects.

We are producing a series of YouTube video tutorials to show people how to build 3D printers from electronic waste.
Currently we are supplying these kits to high schools so the students can learn to build and use them.

The 3D printers were designed to use roller bearings (no linear bearings), making them very acurate and long lasting.
These printers run 8hrs a day printing high quality parts for more printers.

Sub33D v2.07 $65 USD full sized recycled e-waste 3D printer
features:

  • New version with improved x-axis motor and idler mounts
  • Print area 200W x 200D x 180H
  • High accuracy long life 604zz bearing construction (No linear bearings)
  • 10mm rods throughout design (stiffer, less vibration)
  • Ridged frame design (minimize frame flexing)
  • Designed to Utilise recycled printer, PC and general e-waste components from e-waste recyclers
  • Utilizes thingiverse extruder components:
    • E3D_v6_Compact_Extruder_for_i3_Rework

Component cost excluding recycled components under $65 USD, purchased components:

  • J-Head Hotend, short distance $4.50
  • ATMEGA2560 board $5.95
  • Ramps 1.4 shield $4.28
  • 4 x DRV8825 Stepper Motor Driver $6.20
  • Optical Endstop Switch For RAMPS 1.4 $0.68
  • 2 x Micro switch - roller leaver $0.80
  • 2 x GT2 20 Tooth pulley and 2m GT2 belt $3.85
  • 100K ohm NTC 3950 1% Thermistor $0.80
  • RAMPS1.4 2004 LCD Display $8.09
  • 30 x 604zz bearings $4.23
  • Heat bed $6.08
  • 0.5kg 3D Printer Filament ABS 1.75mm $8.00
  • 100x 2.54mm pitch Dupont connectors $0.76

  • Threaded rod, small number of screws, Wade Extruder bolt and misc items ~$10.00

  • Total (inc delivery) $64.22

  • Please checkout file "Sub33D price info v2.07.pdf" for links to online components and prices as of 2016-03-20

Main recycled components:

  • 8mm acrylic sheets from PC LCD monitors
  • 10mm chrome steel rods recovered from office printers
  • Nema 17 stepper motors recovered from office printers
  • ATX 350W PC power supply
  • rubber bushes, heatsinks, fans recovered from office printers and PC's
  • Screws recovered from general e-waste
  • 16mm laminated particle board base plate recovered from old kitchen cabinet material
  • Heatbed glass recovered from office printer
  • Wiring recovered from Ethernet LAN cable (multi stranded wire, not solid core) and PC power cords (10A wires)
  • Bearings recovered from office printer stepper motors (non Nema type stepper motors)

Built and filmed on location:

  • Substation 33 (www.substation33.com.au)
  • 31 Mary St, Kingston QLD 4114, Australia
  • Ph +61 (07) 3826 1533

Please check out the following Youtube video build sequence play list for detailed build instructions (still under construction):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0eCutGJ9l7U&list=PLW8e88EbKrS9L1Py1hJ-ydUP7O0o1GQaK

comments.text: Just so you know, those cheap RAMPS boards have issues. Their polyfuses can false-trip, the MOSFETs often don't fully turn on (thus making them produce more heat because their internal resistance is higher than wanted) and the power connectors and traces are not rated to take the full amount of current they claim to take.
comments.author: konp69

comments.text: Thanks for the heads, up, we have also seen most of these issues, we solder a 75A logic level FET in parallel with the onboard heat bed FET and are looking to replace the power connector with a MT60 (have had many power connector burn out issues already)

comments.text: Hello, I'll keep you posted on how my quest goes...  While my Dad liked to go to the pick-n-pull for auto parts, I hope some one has something similar out here for electronics.  I wouldn't be surprised if there is a law against e-waste salvaging here in California due to chemicals that can be found in the parts. comments.author: sschm9

comments.text: Thanks for that, I would be more than happy to help you with your build where I can and answer any of your questions and issues etc. I have uploaded "sub33d-v2.xx sample marlin firmware.zip" which you can use to get the printer running, there are heaps of great youtube videos on how to install the firmware onto the ATMega2560, Good luck with the e-waste hunting
comments.author: rpayne101

comments.text: Thanks for firmware upload.  I've a little news on the e-waste hunt.  The surplus warehouse I like to go to for office supplies and odd stuff will set aside things I request from their e-waste recycling.  They will charge a small fee for recouping lost revenue and said not to breakdown the items on the premises.  For monitors its around $5, USD, which I can live with.  The printer parts may be a problem.  They'll set it aside too, but they did ask for a make and model type.  You mentioned the large multi function printers and I am assuming you meant the photo copier that scans, prints, sorts and staples?  Is there a particular brand you pull the parts out of or would any MFC be fine?  My main problem would be getting the MFC back to my home... err... correction... more like my wife letting me bring one or two MFC's back home... :)
comments.author: sschm9

comments.text: I have created and uploaded the drill guide "Sub33D_v2.07_Drill_Template.pdf" in metric. I would still recommend finding a recycler who dismantle's the e-waste, as it could be very hit and miss with the monitors and MFC printers (the old fluro LED monitors can have 6 or 8mm plates, the MFC's often have DC servo's, some have no nema steppers while others have many), I can have a look in the SF area for some recyclers to suggest if you like? (would definitely not recommend dismantling at home ;-)
comments.author: rpayne101

comments.text: Thanks for the drill template, downloaded it and will look at over the weekend.  I'll keep looking around to see what I find.  I have a couple of places to call that are near by.  If you could have a look as well I would greatly appreciate it.  Thanks again for your help.
comments.author: sschm9

comments.text: Had a look at e-waste recycling in your area, try http://www.unwaste.com and http://www.greencitizen.com , they both dismantle, resell and refurbish electronics, parts etc (same as us)
comments.author: rpayne101

comments.text: Thanks for the leads.  Unfortunately Universal Waste Management, unwaste.com doesn't break down printers, scanner or copiers for parts.  I haven't been able to get a hold of anyone at Greencitizen yet.  Common thing I have been told by all the e-waste recyclers is that there is no way to re-coup labor cost for pulling parts.  Computers and printers that are being sold are somewhat new models, 5 year old stuff.  Couple of places told me that they crush the copy machines as soon as they get them.  This does make finding parts hard and a bit on the expensive side, pending on the item.  I'm still looking around though, friends, family, work, e-bay, craigslist and the lot...  Hopefully I will hit pay dirt..
comments.author: sschm9

comments.text: Thanks for the feed back, although sad/sorry to hear the results, we use volunteers/people out of work to dismantle our e-waste and assemble the 3D printers and other projects to gain skills/experience etc, sounds like there may be some untapped business opportunities there?
comments.author: rpayne101

comments.text: I'm not sure about this as an untapped business opportunities but, what you have going on sounds like a good community thing.  Over here, California, the trade/vocational training is dying a slow death.  We seem to be more focused on Engineers than design drafters or fabricators.  I'm in the Marine Industry and as a Marine Drafter I'm watching my profession going away.

description.text:
Here is my magnetic pen holder for Polargraph gondola .

I designed it to very quick pen exchange without loose any coordinate or made heavy movements aligning the pen. I'ts really atach and deatach the pen very quick and softly.

VIdeo : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCL0oEaDoE4&feature=youtu.be

Material needed :

2 - printed parts
3 - M3 bolts and screws
3 - Magnets 5mm x 5 diameter from: www.supermagnete.com Item: S-05-05-N Disc magnet Ø 5 mm, height 5 mm, neodymium, N45, nickel-plated

Process :
-Print the parts and clear the holes to let enter the magnets softly and firmly.
-Insert the magnets with a lillte drop cyanoacrylate glue , Must be inserted in the same position to define a correct plane , and let 0,5mm over the plastic face.
-Insert the bolts and screws to fix the pen.

1000 thanks to polargraph bigBoss, Sandy, to let us introduce in this fantastic polar world !

Enjoy ! :)
